questions.notes: As engineered structures, many bird nests are uniquely flexible yet cohesive. A research team led by Yashraj Bhosale wanted to better understand the mechanics behind these structural properties. Bhosale’s team used laboratory models that simulated the arrangement of flexible sticks into nest-like structures. The researchers analyzed the points where sticks touched one another. When pressure was applied to the model nests, the number of contact points between the sticks increased, making the structures stiffer.
questions.student_goal: Present the primary aim of the research study.

answer_choices.A: Bhosale’s team wanted to better understand the mechanics behind bird nests’ uniquely flexible yet cohesive structural properties.
answer_choices.B: The researchers used laboratory models that simulated the arrangement of flexible sticks and analyzed the points where sticks touched one another.
answer_choices.C: After analyzing the points where sticks touched, the researchers found that the structures became stiffer when pressure was applied.
answer_choices.D: As analyzed by Bhosale’s team, bird nests are uniquely flexible yet cohesive engineered structures.

questions.rationale: Choice A clearly states the study's primary aim by focusing on understanding the mechanics behind the unique structural properties of bird nests, whereas the other options either describe the methodology or outcomes.

questions.notes: The Atlantic Monthly magazine was first published in 1857 and focused on politics, art, and literature. In 2019, historian Cathryn Halverson published the book Faraway Women and the “Atlantic Monthly.” The book’s subject is female authors whose autobiographies appeared in the magazine in the early 1900s. One of the authors discussed is Juanita Harrison.
questions.student_goal: Introduce Cathryn Halverson’s book to an audience already familiar with the Atlantic Monthly.

answer_choices.A: Cathryn Halverson’s Faraway Women and the “Atlantic Monthly” discusses female authors whose autobiographies appeared in the magazine in the early 1900s.
answer_choices.B: A magazine called the Atlantic Monthly, referred to in Cathryn Halverson’s book title, was first published in 1857.
answer_choices.C: Faraway Women and the “Atlantic Monthly” features contributors to the Atlantic Monthly, first published in 1857 as a magazine focusing on politics, art, and literature.
answer_choices.D: An author discussed by Cathryn Halverson is Juanita Harrison, whose autobiography appeared in the Atlantic Monthly in the early 1900s.

questions.rationale: Choice A directly introduces Halverson’s book along with its content, making it appropriate for an audience that is already familiar with the Atlantic Monthly. The other options either provide unnecessary background or focus on details that do not effectively introduce the book.

questions.notes: Organisms release cellular material (such as hair or skin) into their environment, and the DNA from these substances is known as environmental DNA (eDNA). Researchers collect and analyze eDNA to detect the presence of species that are difficult to observe. Geneticist Sara Oyler-McCance’s research team analyzed eDNA in water samples from the Florida Everglades to detect invasive constrictor snake species. The study determined a 91% probability of detecting Burmese python eDNA in a given location.
questions.student_goal: Present the study to an audience already familiar with environmental DNA.

answer_choices.A: Sara Oyler-McCance’s researchers analyzed eDNA in water samples from the Florida Everglades for evidence of invasive constrictor snakes, which are difficult to observe.
answer_choices.B: An analysis of eDNA can detect the presence of invasive species that are difficult to observe, such as constrictor snakes.
answer_choices.C: Researchers found Burmese python eDNA, or environmental DNA, in water samples; eDNA is the DNA in released cellular materials, such as shed skin cells.
answer_choices.D: Sara Oyler-McCance’s researchers analyzed environmental DNA (eDNA)—that is, DNA from cellular materials released by organisms—in water samples from the Florida Everglades.

questions.rationale: Choice A effectively presents the study by focusing on the research process and its application without over-explaining what eDNA is, which is suitable for an audience already familiar with the topic.

questions.notes: Sam Maloof (1916–2009) was an American woodworker and furniture designer, and the son of Lebanese immigrants. He received a “genius grant” from the MacArthur Foundation in 1985. The Museum of Fine Arts in Boston owns a rocking chair made by Maloof from walnut wood. The chair features sleek, contoured armrests and seat, and a back consisting of seven spindle-like slats.
questions.student_goal: Describe the rocking chair to an audience unfamiliar with Sam Maloof.

answer_choices.A: With its sleek, contoured armrests and seat, the walnut rocking chair in Boston’s Museum of Fine Arts is just one piece of furniture created by American woodworker Sam Maloof.
answer_choices.B: Sam Maloof was born in 1916 and died in 2009, and during his life, he made a chair that you can see if you visit the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston.
answer_choices.C: Furniture designer Sam Maloof was a recipient of one of the John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation’s “genius grants.”
answer_choices.D: The rocking chair is made from walnut, and it has been shaped such that its armrests and seat are sleek and contoured.

questions.rationale: Choice A combines a description of the chair with the relevant information about Sam Maloof, which is ideal for an audience unfamiliar with him. The other choices either focus too much on biographical details or lack a complete description of the chair.

questions.notes: Species belonging to the Orchidaceae family are found in both tropical and temperate environments. However, the diversity of Orchidaceae species in temperate forests, such as those in Oaxaca, Mexico, has not been well studied. Arelee Estefanía Muñoz-Hernández led a study to determine how many different Orchidaceae species are present in these forests. Her team collected orchids each month for a year at a site in Oaxaca and found that 74 species were present.
questions.student_goal: Present the study and its findings.

answer_choices.A: A study led by Arelee Estefanía Muñoz-Hernández identified a total of 74 Orchidaceae species in the temperate forests of Oaxaca, Mexico.
answer_choices.B: There are orchids in many environments, but there are 74 Orchidaceae species in Oaxaca, Mexico.
answer_choices.C: Oaxaca, Mexico, is home to temperate forests containing 74 Orchidaceae species.
answer_choices.D: Arelee Estefanía Muñoz-Hernández and her team wanted to know how many different Orchidaceae species are present in the forests of Oaxaca, Mexico, so they conducted a study to collect orchids.

questions.rationale: Choice A clearly presents both the study and its key finding, making it the most effective option for the student’s goal.

questions.notes: The Philadelphia and Lancaster Turnpike was built between 1792 and 1794 and was the first private turnpike in the United States. It connected the cities of Philadelphia and Lancaster in Pennsylvania and was sixty-two miles long.
questions.student_goal: Emphasize the distance covered by the Philadelphia and Lancaster Turnpike.

answer_choices.A: The sixty-two-mile-long Philadelphia and Lancaster Turnpike connected the Pennsylvania cities of Philadelphia and Lancaster.
answer_choices.B: The Philadelphia and Lancaster Turnpike was the first private turnpike in the United States.
answer_choices.C: The Philadelphia and Lancaster Turnpike, which connected two Pennsylvania cities, was built between 1792 and 1794.
answer_choices.D: A historic Pennsylvania road, the Philadelphia and Lancaster Turnpike was completed in 1794.

questions.rationale: Choice A directly emphasizes the distance by stating that the turnpike is sixty-two miles long and clearly identifies the connected cities.

questions.notes: The Million Song Dataset (MSD) includes main audio features (like loudness and pitch intervals) and descriptive tags for popular songs. Many algorithms use these audio features to predict a new song’s popularity, but they may fail when a song has varying acoustic traits. Algorithms based on descriptive tags, which describe fixed traits such as genre, are more reliable predictors of popularity.
questions.student_goal: Explain a disadvantage of relying on audio features to predict a song’s popularity.

answer_choices.A: Many popularity-predicting algorithms are based on a song’s audio features, such as loudness and pitch intervals.
answer_choices.B: Algorithms based on audio features may misidentify the main features of a song with varying acoustic traits, making such algorithms less reliable predictors of popularity than those based on fixed traits.
answer_choices.C: Audio features describe acoustic traits such as pitch intervals, which may vary within a song, whereas descriptive tags describe fixed traits such as genre, which are reliable predictors of popularity.
answer_choices.D: The MSD’s descriptive tags are reliable predictors of a song’s popularity, as the traits they describe are fixed.

questions.rationale: Choice B most effectively explains the disadvantage by stating that reliance on audio features may lead to misidentification of features in songs with varying traits, making these algorithms less reliable compared to those based on fixed traits.

questions.notes: Oracles of the Pink Universe was a 2021 exhibition at the Denver Museum of Art in Colorado, featuring eight artworks by South African artist Simphiwe Ndzube. One of these works is a painting titled Assertion of Will, which depicts three standing figures. The figures wear clothing made of fabric pieces stitched to the painting’s canvas.
questions.student_goal: Describe how fabric is used in the painting Assertion of Will.

answer_choices.A: In Assertion of Will, the figures’ clothing is made of fabric pieces stitched to the painting’s canvas.
answer_choices.B: The exhibition Oracles of the Pink Universe featured artworks by artist Simphiwe Ndzube.
answer_choices.C: Depicting three standing, clothed figures, Assertion of Will is a painting by Simphiwe Ndzube.
answer_choices.D: Simphiwe Ndzube’s Assertion of Will was one of eight artworks exhibited in Oracles of the Pink Universe at the Denver Museum of Art.

questions.rationale: Choice A directly describes the use of fabric in the painting by explaining that the figures’ clothing is made of fabric pieces stitched to the canvas, which meets the student’s goal.

questions.notes: Platinum is a rare and expensive metal used as a catalyst for chemical reactions, and platinum catalysts typically require a large amount of the metal to be effective. Researcher Jianbo Tang and his colleagues created a platinum catalyst by combining platinum with liquid gallium. Their catalyst was highly effective while requiring only trace amounts of platinum (0.0001% of the atoms in the mixture).
questions.student_goal: Explain an advantage of the new platinum catalyst developed by Jianbo Tang and his colleagues.

answer_choices.A: Researcher Jianbo Tang and his colleagues created a platinum catalyst that combines platinum, a rare and expensive metal, with liquid gallium.
answer_choices.B: Like other platinum catalysts, the new platinum catalyst requires a particular amount of the metal to be effective.
answer_choices.C: Platinum is a rare and expensive metal that is used as a catalyst for chemical reactions; however, platinum catalysts typically require a large amount of platinum to be effective.
answer_choices.D: While still highly effective, the new platinum catalyst requires far less of the rare and expensive metal than do other platinum catalysts.

questions.rationale: Choice D highlights the advantage of the new catalyst by emphasizing that it requires far less platinum, addressing the cost and rarity of the metal.

questions.notes: Muslins are woven cotton fabrics used in various ways. Dhaka muslin is a handmade fabric produced in Dhaka, Bangladesh, known for its extremely fine weave and primarily used to make luxury clothing. Sheeting muslin is machine-made in factories, has a coarse weave, and is primarily used for upholstering furniture and creating backdrops for theater sets.
questions.student_goal: Emphasize a difference between the two types of muslin.

answer_choices.A: Dhaka muslin is a handmade fabric with an extremely fine weave, while sheeting muslin is machine made with a coarse weave.
answer_choices.B: Dhaka muslin and sheeting muslin are two different types of woven cotton fabrics.
answer_choices.C: Muslins can be used in a variety of ways, from making luxury clothing to upholstering furniture and creating backdrops for theater sets.
answer_choices.D: Sheeting muslin is machine made, has a coarse weave, and is used for furniture and theater sets.

questions.rationale: Choice A effectively contrasts the two by highlighting the differences in production method and weave quality between Dhaka muslin and sheeting muslin.

questions.notes: Some powerful works of literature have so influenced readers that new legislation has been passed as a result. The Interesting Narrative of the Life of Olaudah Equiano (1789) is the autobiography of a man who endured slavery on both sides of the Atlantic. Equiano’s book contributed to the passage of the Slave Trade Act of 1807. The Jungle (1906) is a fictional work by Upton Sinclair that describes unsanitary conditions in US meatpacking plants. Sinclair’s book contributed to the passage of the Pure Food and Drug Act in 1906.
questions.student_goal: Emphasize a difference between the two books.

answer_choices.A: Although both are powerful works of literature that contributed to new legislation, Equiano’s book is an autobiography, while Sinclair’s is fictional.
answer_choices.B: They may have written about different topics, but Equiano and Sinclair both influenced readers.
answer_choices.C: The 1807 Slave Trade Act resulted in part from a book by Equiano, while the 1906 Pure Food and Drug Act resulted in part from a book by Sinclair.
answer_choices.D: The Interesting Narrative of the Life of Olaudah Equiano and The Jungle are two works of literature that contributed to new legislation (concerning the slave trade and food safety, respectively).

questions.rationale: Choice A is the best answer. It emphasizes a difference between the two books by contrasting their genres: Equiano’s being an autobiography and Sinclair’s being a work of fiction.

questions.notes: The Azores is a group of islands about 870 miles off the coast of Portugal. Historians have long believed that in the fifteenth century Portuguese mariners were the first humans to populate the Azores. A 2015 study coauthored by Sofia Gabriel and Maria da Luz Mathias found that Vikings from Scandinavia may have populated the Azores as early as the ninth century. The researchers found a genetic connection between house mice in the Azores and house mice in Scandinavia. House mice may have traveled from Scandinavia to the Azores on Viking ships.
questions.student_goal: Specify who may have first populated the Azores, according to the 2015 study.

answer_choices.A: Historians have long believed that the first humans to populate the Azores, a group of islands about 870 miles off the coast of Portugal, arrived in the fifteenth century.
answer_choices.B: Portuguese mariners may not have been the first humans to populate the Azores.
answer_choices.C: In their 2015 study, the researchers found a genetic connection between house mice in the Azores and those in Scandinavia.
answer_choices.D: According to a 2015 study, the first humans to populate the Azores may have been Vikings from Scandinavia, not mariners from Portugal as previously believed.

questions.rationale: Choice D is the best answer. It directly states that, according to the 2015 study, Vikings from Scandinavia may have been the first to populate the Azores, contrasting with the longstanding belief regarding Portuguese mariners.

questions.notes: Allan Houser was a Chiricahua Warm Springs Apache sculptor, illustrator, and painter. Many of his sculptures featured Native American figures. He depicted this subject matter using abstract, modernist forms, developing a distinctive style that influenced many other artists. His well-known sculpture Sacred Rain Arrow was pictured on the State of Oklahoma license plate.
questions.student_goal: Describe the distinctive style of Houser’s sculptures.

answer_choices.A: A sculptor, illustrator, and painter, Houser developed a distinctive style for portraying Native American figures.
answer_choices.B: Houser’s sculptures employ abstract, modernist forms to depict Native American figures.
answer_choices.C: Many other artists have been influenced by the style of Houser’s sculptures.
answer_choices.D: The sculpture Sacred Rain Arrow is a well-known example of Houser’s style.

questions.rationale: Choice B is the best answer because it specifically describes Houser’s distinctive style by noting that his sculptures employ abstract, modernist forms to depict Native American figures.

questions.notes: In the midst of the US Civil War, Susie Taylor escaped slavery and fled to Union-army-occupied St. Simons Island off the Georgia coast. She began working for an all-Black army regiment as a nurse and teacher. In 1902, she published a book about the time she spent with the regiment. Her book was the only Civil War memoir to be published by a Black woman. It is still available to readers in print and online.
questions.student_goal: Emphasize the uniqueness of Taylor’s accomplishment.

answer_choices.A: Taylor fled to St. Simons Island, which was then occupied by the Union army, for whom she began working.
answer_choices.B: After escaping slavery, Taylor began working for an all-Black army regiment as a nurse and teacher.
answer_choices.C: The book Taylor wrote about the time she spent with the regiment is still available to readers in print and online.
answer_choices.D: Taylor was the only Black woman to publish a Civil War memoir.

questions.rationale: Choice D is the best answer because it directly emphasizes the unique nature of Taylor’s accomplishment by stating that she was the only Black woman to publish a Civil War memoir.

questions.notes: One of history’s greatest libraries was the House of Wisdom in Baghdad, Iraq. It was founded in the eighth century with the goal of preserving all the world’s knowledge. Scholars at the House of Wisdom collected ancient and contemporary texts from Greece, India, and elsewhere and translated them into Arabic. Writings included those of the Greek philosopher Aristotle and the Indian mathematician Aryabhata. The House of Wisdom used Chinese papermaking technology to create paper versions to be studied and shared.
questions.student_goal: Explain how the House of Wisdom preserved the world’s knowledge.

answer_choices.A: The House of Wisdom was known for bringing together knowledge from around the world, including from Greece, India, and China.
answer_choices.B: Founded in Iraq in the eighth century, the House of Wisdom employed many scholars as translators.
answer_choices.C: Writings from the Greek philosopher Aristotle and the Indian mathematician Aryabhata were preserved at the House of Wisdom.
answer_choices.D: The House of Wisdom collected writings from different countries and created paper versions in Arabic to be studied and shared.

questions.rationale: Choice D is the best answer because it details the process of preservation: the collection, translation, and creation of paper versions in Arabic, making the global knowledge accessible.

questions.notes: Cities tend to have a wide range of flowering vegetation in parks, yards, and gardens, providing a varied diet for honeybees that strengthens their immune systems. On average, 62.5 percent of bees in an urban area will survive a harsh winter. In contrast, rural areas are often dominated by monoculture crops such as corn or wheat, where only about 40 percent of honeybees survive a harsh winter.
questions.student_goal: Make and support a generalization about honeybees.

answer_choices.A: Cities tend to have a wider range of flowering vegetation than do rural areas, which are often dominated by monoculture crops.
answer_choices.B: In urban areas, over 60 percent of honeybees, on average, will survive a harsh winter, whereas in rural areas, only 40 percent will.
answer_choices.C: The strength of honeybees’ immune systems depends on what the bees eat, and a varied diet is more available to bees in an urban area than to those in a rural area.
answer_choices.D: Honeybees are more likely to thrive in cities than in rural areas because the varied diet available in urban areas strengthens the bees’ immune systems.

questions.rationale: Choice D is the best answer as it makes the generalization that honeybees thrive better in cities than rural areas and supports it with information about the benefits of a varied urban diet on their immune systems.

questions.notes: In 2018, researchers Adwait Deshpande, Shreejata Gupta, and Anindya Sinha were observing wild macaques in India’s Bandipur National Park. They saw macaques calling out to and gesturing at humans who were eating or carrying food. To test whether the macaques were intentionally trying to persuade the humans to share their food, they designed a study. In the study trials, macaques frequently called out to and gestured at humans holding food, and called out and gestured less frequently at empty-handed humans.
questions.student_goal: Present the study’s results.

answer_choices.A: Macaques in the study called out to and gestured more frequently at humans holding food than at empty-handed humans.
answer_choices.B: In 2018, researchers who had observed macaques in India’s Bandipur National Park calling out to and gesturing at humans designed a study.
answer_choices.C: The researchers hoped to find out if the macaques were intentionally communicating to try to persuade humans to share their food.
answer_choices.D: The researchers studied how macaques behaved around both humans holding food and empty-handed humans.

questions.rationale: Choice A is the best answer because it clearly states the study’s results—namely, that macaques called out and gestured more when humans were holding food, which directly reflects the findings.

questions.notes: Yellowstone is a national park in the northwest United States. In 1995, gray wolves were reintroduced into the park. Since then, the number of gray wolves in the park has stabilized at roughly 100, a figure believed to be the park’s carrying capacity (the maximum number of a species that an environment’s resources can sustain over time).
questions.student_goal: Specify the number of gray wolves in Yellowstone.

answer_choices.A: Gray wolves were reintroduced into Yellowstone, a national park in the northwest United States, in 1995.
answer_choices.B: As of 1995, there were gray wolves living in Yellowstone, a national park in the northwest United States.
answer_choices.C: The carrying capacity of an environment, such as Yellowstone, describes the maximum number of species that the environment can sustain over time.
answer_choices.D: Yellowstone is a national park that has roughly 100 gray wolves living in it.

questions.rationale: Choice D is the best answer because it uses the specific detail about the stabilization of the gray wolf population to indicate that there are roughly 100 gray wolves in the park.

questions.notes: In 2013, archaeologists studied cat bone fragments found in the ruins of Quanhucun, a Chinese farming village. The fragments were estimated to be 5,300 years old, and a chemical analysis revealed that the cats had consumed large amounts of grain. This grain consumption is evidence that the Quanhucun cats may have been domesticated.
questions.student_goal: Present the Quanhucun study and its conclusions.

answer_choices.A: As part of a 2013 study of cat domestication, a chemical analysis was conducted on cat bone fragments found in Quanhucun, China.
answer_choices.B: A 2013 analysis of cat bone fragments found in Quanhucun, China, suggests that cats there may have been domesticated 5,300 years ago.
answer_choices.C: In 2013, archaeologists studied what cats in Quanhucun, China, had eaten more than 5,000 years ago.
answer_choices.D: Cat bone fragments estimated to be 5,300 years old were found in Quanhucun, China, in 2013.

questions.rationale: Choice B is the best answer because it presents both the study (cat bone fragment analysis) and its conclusion—that the evidence suggests cats in Quanhucun may have been domesticated 5,300 years ago.

questions.notes: Novelist Willa Cather grew up in Nebraska and attended the University of Nebraska-Lincoln. Some of Cather’s best-known novels are set in Nebraska. Two such novels are O Pioneers! (1913) and My Ántonia (1918). Cather’s novels describe the experiences of immigrants who settled in the Great Plains.
questions.student_goal: Identify the setting of Cather’s novel My Ántonia.

answer_choices.A: My Ántonia is set in Nebraska, where Cather grew up.
answer_choices.B: Cather, author of My Ántonia, described the experiences of immigrants in her novels.
answer_choices.C: Among Cather’s best-known novels are O Pioneers! (1913) and My Ántonia (1918).
answer_choices.D: Cather attended the University of Nebraska-Lincoln and set some of her novels in Nebraska.

questions.rationale: Choice A is the best answer because it directly identifies Nebraska as the setting of My Ántonia, which is supported by the notes indicating Cather's background and the settings of her novels.

questions.notes: Muckrakers were journalists who sought to expose corruption in US institutions during the Progressive Era (1897–1920). Ida Tarbell was a muckraker who investigated the Standard Oil Company. She interviewed Standard Oil Company executives, oil industry workers, and public officials. She examined thousands of pages of the company’s internal communications, including letters and financial records. Her book The History of the Standard Oil Company (1904) exposed the company’s unfair business practices.
questions.student_goal: Emphasize the thoroughness of Ida Tarbell’s investigation of the Standard Oil Company.

answer_choices.A: Ida Tarbell not only interviewed Standard Oil executives, oil industry workers, and public officials but also examined thousands of pages of the company’s internal communications.
answer_choices.B: Ida Tarbell, who investigated the Standard Oil Company, was a muckraker (a journalist who sought to expose corruption in US institutions during the Progressive Era, 1897–1920).
answer_choices.C: As part of her investigation of the Standard Oil Company, muckraker Ida Tarbell conducted interviews.
answer_choices.D: Published in 1904, muckraker Ida Tarbell’s book The History of the Standard Oil Company exposed the company’s unfair business practices.

questions.rationale: Choice A is the best answer. It describes Tarbell’s investigation in detail by mentioning both her interviews and her extensive examination of internal communications, clearly demonstrating the thoroughness of her work.

questions.notes: John Carver was one of the 41 signatories of the Mayflower Compact. The Mayflower Compact was a legal agreement among the pilgrims that immigrated to Plymouth Colony. It was created in 1620 to establish a common government. It states that the pilgrims who signed it wanted to 'plant the first colony in the northern parts of Virginia' under King James. Carver became the first governor of Plymouth Colony.
questions.student_goal: Specify the reason the Mayflower Compact was created.

answer_choices.A: Stating that its signatories wanted to 'plant the first colony in the northern parts of Virginia,' the Mayflower Compact was a legal agreement among the pilgrims that immigrated to Plymouth Colony.
answer_choices.B: Created in 1620, the Mayflower Compact states that the pilgrims wanted to 'plant the first colony in the northern parts of Virginia.'
answer_choices.C: The Mayflower Compact was created to establish a common government among the pilgrims that immigrated to Plymouth Colony.
answer_choices.D: The Mayflower Compact had 41 signatories, including John Carver, the first governor of Plymouth Colony.

questions.rationale: Choice C is the best answer. It specifically states that the Compact was created to establish a common government among the pilgrims, directly addressing the reason for its creation.

questions.notes: Jordan Bennett is a Mi’Kmaq visual artist. The Mi’Kmaq are a First Nations people in North America. Bennett’s paintings pay homage to traditional Mi’Kmaq craftsmanship and have been displayed in over 75 exhibitions. His 2017 exhibition Wije’wi was held at the Grenfell Art Gallery. His 2018 exhibition Ketu’elmita’jik was held at the Art Gallery of Nova Scotia.
questions.student_goal: Emphasize the order in which two of Jordan Bennett’s exhibitions were held.

answer_choices.A: Jordan Bennett’s 2017 exhibition Wije’wi was followed a year later by his exhibition Ketu’elmita’jik.
answer_choices.B: Jordan Bennett’s paintings, some of which appeared in 2017 and 2018 exhibitions, pay homage to traditional Mi’Kmaq craftsmanship.
answer_choices.C: Mi’Kmaq visual artist Jordan Bennett has displayed his work in over 75 exhibitions, including Wije’wi and Ketu’elmita’jik.
answer_choices.D: Jordan Bennett’s 2018 exhibition Ketu’elmita’jik was held at the Art Gallery of Nova Scotia; another was held at the Grenfell Art Gallery.

questions.rationale: Choice A is the best answer. It clearly emphasizes the order by stating that the 2017 exhibition was followed a year later by the 2018 exhibition.

questions.notes: Marine biologist Camille Jazmin Gaynus studies coral reefs. Coral reefs are vital underwater ecosystems that provide habitats to 25% of all marine species. Reefs can include up to 8,000 species of fish, such as toadfish, seahorses, and clown triggerfish. The Amazon Reef is a coral reef in Brazil. It is one of the largest known reefs in the world.
questions.student_goal: Introduce the scientist and her field of study to a new audience.

answer_choices.A: Located in Brazil, the Amazon Reef is one of the largest known coral reefs in the world.
answer_choices.B: Marine biologist Camille Jazmin Gaynus studies coral reefs, vital underwater ecosystems that provide homes to 25% of all marine species.
answer_choices.C: Providing homes to 25% of all marine species, including up to 8,000 species of fish, coral reefs are vital underwater ecosystems and thus of great interest to marine biologists.
answer_choices.D: As Camille Jazmin Gaynus knows well, coral reefs are vital underwater ecosystems, providing homes to thousands of species of fish.

questions.rationale: Choice B is the best answer because it clearly introduces Camille Jazmin Gaynus as a marine biologist and explains that she studies coral reefs, which are described with significant supporting details.

questions.notes: In 1971, experimental musician Pauline Oliveros created Sonic Meditations. Sonic Meditations is not music but rather a series of sound-based exercises called meditations. Each meditation consists of instructions for participants to make, imagine, listen to, or remember sounds. The instructions for Meditation V state, 'walk so silently that the bottoms of your feet become ears.' Those for Meditation XVIII state, 'listen to a sound until you no longer recognize it.'
questions.student_goal: Provide an explanation and an example of Oliveros’s Sonic Meditations.

answer_choices.A: Sonic Meditations is not music but rather a series of sound-based meditations that consist of instructions; Meditation XVIII, for instance, instructs participants to 'listen to a sound until you no longer recognize it.'
answer_choices.B: In 1971, Oliveros created Sonic Meditations, a series of meditations that consist of instructions for participants to make, imagine, listen to, or remember sounds.
answer_choices.C: "Walk so silently that the bottoms of your feet become ears" is one example of the instructions found in Oliveros’s Sonic Meditations.
answer_choices.D: While both meditations consist of instructions, Meditation XVIII instructs participants to 'listen,' whereas Meditation V instructs participants to 'walk.'

questions.rationale: Choice A is the best answer because it both explains what Sonic Meditations are and provides a specific example (Meditation XVIII) to illustrate the concept.

questions.notes: British musicians John Lennon and Paul McCartney shared writing credit for numerous Beatles songs. Many Lennon-McCartney songs were actually written by either Lennon or McCartney, not by both. The exact authorship of specific parts of many Beatles songs, such as the verse for 'In My Life,' is disputed. Mark Glickman, Jason Brown, and Ryan Song used statistical methods to analyze the musical content of Beatles songs. They concluded that there is 18.9% probability that McCartney wrote the verse for 'In My Life,' stating that the verse is 'consistent with Lennon’s songwriting style.'
questions.student_goal: Make a generalization about the kind of study conducted by Glickman, Brown, and Song.

answer_choices.A: Based on statistical analysis, Glickman, Brown, and Song claim that John Lennon wrote the verse of 'In My Life.'
answer_choices.B: There is only an 18.9% probability that Paul McCartney wrote the verse for 'In My Life'; John Lennon is the more likely author.
answer_choices.C: It is likely that John Lennon, not Paul McCartney, wrote the verse for 'In My Life.'
answer_choices.D: Researchers have used statistical methods to address questions of authorship within the field of music.

questions.rationale: Choice D is the best answer because it generalizes the type of study conducted, noting that statistical methods were used to address authorship issues in music, rather than focusing solely on the specific findings.

questions.notes: The Heartbeat of Wounded Knee: Native America from 1890 to the Present is a history book by Ojibwe author David Treuer. In a review, a critic for The Economist noted that “Treuer’s storytelling skills shine” and that the book is an “elegant handling of [a] complex narrative.” A critic for O, The Oprah Magazine called it “a marvel of research and storytelling.” A critic for the Missoulian dubbed it “a monumental achievement.”
questions.student_goal: Emphasize a similarity in how critics responded to Treuer’s book.

answer_choices.A: Treuer’s book, which was widely reviewed, focuses on Native American history from 1890 to the present.
answer_choices.B: Dubbed 'a monumental achievement' by the Missoulian, Treuer’s book documents over a century of Native American history.
answer_choices.C: Critics praised Treuer’s book for its compelling narrative, with O, The Oprah Magazine calling it 'a marvel of research and storytelling' and The Economist likewise writing that 'Treuer’s storytelling skills shine' and that the book is an 'elegant handling of [a] complex narrative.'
answer_choices.D: While the Missoulian focused on the book’s broader achievement, The Economist zeroed in on Treuer’s storytelling skills.

questions.rationale: Choice C is the best answer because it emphasizes the similarity in critics’ responses by noting that both The Economist and O, The Oprah Magazine praised Treuer’s storytelling and narrative style.

questions.notes: In 2013, paleontology professor Hesham Sallam and his students from Mansoura University in Egypt made a discovery. The team found a partial dinosaur skeleton at a site in Egypt’s Dakhla Oasis. The skeleton belonged to a dinosaur species that lived approximately 80 million years ago. The new species was named Mansourasaurus to recognize the team that discovered it.
questions.student_goal: Explain the origin of the species’ name.

answer_choices.A: Mansourasaurus, a new species discovered in Egypt in 2013, lived approximately 80 million years ago.
answer_choices.B: A partial dinosaur skeleton found in Egypt’s Dakhla Oasis belonged to a species named Mansourasaurus.
answer_choices.C: Mansourasaurus, a species that lived approximately 80 million years ago, was discovered in 2013 by Egyptian paleontologist Hesham Sallam and a team of university students.
answer_choices.D: The new species was named Mansourasaurus to recognize the team that discovered it, a professor and students from Mansoura University.

questions.rationale: Choice D is the best answer because it directly explains that the species was named Mansourasaurus to honor the team from Mansoura University that discovered the skeleton.

questions.notes: Freddie Wong (born 1985) is a director and special effects artist from the United States. He is best known for the action-comedy web series Video Game High School (VGHS). VGHS premiered in 2012 on RocketJump, a YouTube channel that Wong cocreated. The series was celebrated for its inventive video game–centric world and high-quality special effects. VGHS was nominated for a Producers Guild Award for Outstanding Digital Series.
questions.student_goal: Begin a narrative about Wong’s award-nominated web series.

answer_choices.A: In 2012, director and visual effects artist Freddie Wong launched a new action-comedy web series: Video Game High School.
answer_choices.B: Video Game High School was celebrated for its inventive video game–centric world and high-quality special effects, and it was nominated for a Producer’s Guild Award for Outstanding Digital Series.
answer_choices.C: Wong, cocreator of the YouTube channel RocketJump, would go on to see his web series be nominated for a Producers Guild Award.
answer_choices.D: In 2012, Video Game High School premiered on RocketJump; it would later be nominated for an award.

questions.rationale: Choice A is the best answer because it effectively introduces Freddie Wong and his web series in a narrative style, establishing key details such as the premiere year and genre.

questions.notes: In 2019, Emily Shepard and colleagues in the UK and Germany studied the effect of wind on auks’ success in landing at cliffside nesting sites. They found as wind conditions intensified, the birds needed more attempts in order to make a successful landing. When the wind was still, almost 100% of landing attempts were successful. In a strong breeze, approximately 40% of attempts were successful. In near-gale conditions, only around 20% of attempts were successful.
questions.student_goal: Summarize the study.

answer_choices.A: For a 2019 study, researchers from the UK and Germany collected data on auks’ attempts to land at cliffside nesting sites in different wind conditions.
answer_choices.B: Emily Shepard and her colleagues wanted to know the extent to which wind affected auks’ success in landing at cliffside nesting sites, so they conducted a study.
answer_choices.C: Knowing that auks often need multiple attempts to land at their cliffside nesting sites, Emily Shepard studied the birds’ success rate, which was only around 20% in some conditions.
answer_choices.D: Emily Shepard’s 2019 study of auks’ success in landing at cliffside nesting sites showed that as wind conditions intensified, the birds’ success rate decreased.

questions.rationale: Choice D is the best answer because it concisely summarizes the study by noting both the focus on auks’ landing success and the key finding that increased wind intensity leads to decreased landing success.

questions.passage: Samuel Coleridge-Taylor was a prominent classical music composer from England who toured the US three times in the early 1900s. The child of a West African father and an English mother, Coleridge-Taylor emphasized his mixed‐race ancestry. For example, he referred to himself as Anglo-African. ______blank he incorporated the sounds of traditional African music into his classical music compositions.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?
questions.rationale: Choice A is the best answer because 'In addition,' logically signals that the detail—that Coleridge-Taylor incorporated traditional African sounds into his work—adds to the information already provided about his mixed-race identity.

questions.passage: In her poetry collection Thomas and Beulah, Rita Dove interweaves the titular characters’ personal stories with broader historical narratives. She places Thomas’s journey from the American South to the Midwest in the early 1900s within the larger context of the Great Migration. ______blank Dove sets events from Beulah’s personal life against the backdrop of the US Civil Rights Movement.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?
questions.rationale: Choice D is the best answer because 'Similarly,' signals that, just as Thomas’s experiences are placed in a larger historical context, Beulah’s personal events are also set against a significant historical backdrop.

questions.passage: In a heated debate in biogeography, the field is divided between dispersalists and vicariancists. ______blank there are those who argue that dispersal is the most crucial determining factor in a species’ distribution, and those who insist that vicariance (separation due to geographic barriers) is. Biogeographer Isabel Sanmartín counts herself among neither.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?
questions.rationale: Choice D is the best answer because 'That is,' introduces a clarification, explaining the two competing views (dispersal vs. vicariance) that define the debate in biogeography.

questions.passage: Most of the planets that have been discovered outside our solar system orbit G-type stars, like our Sun. In 2014, ______blank researchers identified a planet orbiting KELT-9, a B-type star more than twice as massive and nearly twice as hot as the Sun. Called KELT-9b, it is one of the hottest planets ever discovered.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?
questions.rationale: Choice B is the best answer because 'however,' signals a contrast. While most planets orbit Sun-like stars, this discovery shows a planet orbiting a much hotter, more massive star.

questions.passage: In 1815, while in exile in Jamaica, Venezuelan revolutionary Simón Bolívar penned a letter praising England’s republican government and expressing hope that Latin American nations seeking independence from Spain might achieve something similar. The letter was addressed to a local merchant, Henry Cullen; ______blank though, Bolívar’s goal was to persuade political leaders from England and Europe to support his cause.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?
questions.rationale: Choice B is the best answer because 'ultimately,' indicates that despite the letter being addressed to a merchant, Bolívar’s final aim was to reach higher-level political figures.

questions.passage: The Babylonian king Hammurabi achieved much during his forty-year reign. He conquered all of Mesopotamia and built Babylon into one of the most powerful cities of the ancient world. Today, ______blank he is mainly remembered for a code of laws inscribed on a seven-foot-tall block of stone: the Code of Hammurabi.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?
questions.rationale: Choice C is the best answer because 'however,' signals a contrast: despite his many achievements, Hammurabi is now primarily remembered for one specific contribution.

questions.passage: Some members of the US Supreme Court have resisted calls to televise the court’s oral arguments, concerned that the participants would be tempted to perform for the cameras (and thus lower the quality of the discourse). ______blank the justices worry that most viewers would not even watch the full deliberations, only short clips that could be misinterpreted and mischaracterized.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?
questions.rationale: Choice B is the best answer because 'Additionally,' indicates that this sentence adds another concern held by the justices regarding televising oral arguments.

questions.passage: Award-winning travel writer Linda Watanabe McFerrin considers the background research she conducts on destinations featured in her travel books to be its own reward. ______blank McFerrin admits to finding the research phase of her work just as fascinating and engaging as exploring a location in person.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?
questions.rationale: Choice D is the best answer because 'In fact,' emphasizes and elaborates on McFerrin's claim, reinforcing that the research phase is as rewarding as the experience of travel.

questions.passage: In 1873, Spanish scientist Santiago Ramón y Cajal observed that brain fibers have distinct boundaries with clear end points, a finding that went against earlier assumptions about the brain. ______blank scientists had assumed that the brain was a continuous web of fused fibers, not a vast network of distinct, individual cells.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?
questions.rationale: Choice B is the best answer because 'Previously,' indicates that before Ramón y Cajal’s observations, scientists held a different, now disproven view of the brain’s structure.

questions.passage: For years, biologists have experimented with using grime-eating bacteria rather than harsh chemicals to clean artworks, and results have been impressive overall. ______blank these bacterial strains—which can metabolize centuries’ worth of oil, glue, dirt, and other surface impurities without creating harmful byproducts—have proven more effective than traditional chemical cleaning methods.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?
questions.rationale: Choice B is the best answer because 'In many cases,' implies that in numerous experiments, the bacterial cleaning methods have been effective, supporting the claim of impressive results.

questions.passage: In 1968, US Congressman John Conyers introduced a bill to establish a national holiday in honor of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. The bill didn’t make it to a vote, but Conyers was determined. He teamed up with Shirley Chisholm, the first Black woman to be elected to Congress, and they resubmitted the bill every session for the next fifteen years. ______blank in 1983, the bill passed.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?
questions.rationale: Choice C is the best answer because 'Finally,' signals that after many years of repeated efforts, the desired outcome was ultimately achieved in 1983.

questions.passage: It has long been thought that humans first crossed a land bridge into the Americas approximately 13,000 years ago. ______blank based on radiocarbon dating of samples uncovered in Mexico, a research team recently suggested that humans may have arrived more than 30,000 years ago—much earlier than previously thought.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?
questions.rationale: Choice C is the best answer because 'However,' signals a contrast between the previously held theory and the new findings based on radiocarbon dating.

questions.passage: Researchers believe that pieces of hull found off Oregon’s coast are from a Spanish cargo ship that was lost in 1697. Stories passed down among the area’s Confederated Tribes of Siletz Indians support this belief. ______blank Siletz stories describe how blocks of beeswax, an item the ship had been carrying, began washing ashore after the ship was lost.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?
questions.rationale: Choice B is the best answer because 'For example,' introduces a specific instance—the beeswax stories—that supports the earlier claim regarding the shipwreck.

questions.passage: Alexander Lawrence Posey (1873–1908) varied his focus and tone depending on the genre in which he was writing. In his poetry, he used heartfelt language to evoke the beauty and peacefulness of his natural surroundings; in his journalism, ______blank he employed humor and satire to comment on political issues affecting his Muskogee Creek community.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?
questions.rationale: Choice D is the best answer because 'by contrast,' signals a clear difference between the tone of his poetry and the tone of his journalism.

questions.passage: Geoscientists have long considered Hawaii’s Mauna Loa volcano to be Earth’s largest shield volcano by volume, measuring approximately 74,000 cubic kilometers. ______blank according to a 2020 study by local geoscientist Michael Garcia, Hawaii’s Pūhāhonu shield volcano is significantly larger, boasting a volume of about 148,000 cubic kilometers.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?
questions.rationale: Choice D is the best answer because 'However,' signals a contrast between the long-held belief about Mauna Loa and the new findings that suggest a different volcano is larger.

questions.passage: The parasitic dodder plant increases its reproductive success by flowering at the same time as the host plant it has latched onto. In 2020, Jianqiang Wu and his colleagues determined that the tiny dodder achieves this ______blank with its host by absorbing and utilizing a protein the host produces when it is about to flower.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?
questions.rationale: Choice A is the best answer because, in this context, 'synchronization' refers to the process of matching the timing of flowering between the dodder and its host. By absorbing a protein produced by the host before it flowers, the dodder is able to flower at the same time.

questions.passage: Sumerian civilization (which lasted from around 3300 to 2000 BCE) ______blank many concepts that persist into present-day civilizations: for example, the first description of the seven-day week appears in the Sumerian Epic of Gilgamesh.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?
questions.rationale: Choice B is the best answer because 'introduced' means to bring into use for the first time. The Sumerians provided the earliest recorded example of many concepts, such as the seven-day week, that continue to influence modern societies.

questions.passage: Physicist Joseph Weber performed ______blank work in gravitational wave research in the 1960s and 1970s, conducting key experiments that scientists later used as the basis for their own investigations that led to the first verified detection of a gravitational wave in 2015.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?
questions.rationale: Choice A is the best answer because 'foundational' means serving as a base on which future work is built. Weber’s experiments laid the groundwork that later led to the detection of gravitational waves.

questions.passage: As an architect in Los Angeles in the 1950s, Helen Liu Fong became known for avoiding ______blank designs in her buildings. Instead of using standard shapes and colors, she typically explored innovative forms and daring hues.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?
questions.rationale: Choice C is the best answer because 'traditional' refers to conventional or standard designs. Fong distinguished herself by rejecting conventional (traditional) forms in favor of innovative approaches.

questions.passage: US traffic signals didn’t always contain the familiar three lights (red, yellow, and green). Traffic lights only ______blank red and green lights until the three-light traffic signal was developed in the 1920s.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?
questions.rationale: Choice B is the best answer because 'featured' means that red and green lights were the standard components of traffic signals before the addition of a yellow light.

questions.passage: Given that the conditions in binary star systems should make planetary formation nearly impossible, it’s not surprising that the existence of planets in such systems has lacked ______blank explanation. Roman Rafikov and Kedron Silsbee shed light on the subject when they used modeling to determine a complex set of factors that could support planets’ development.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?
questions.rationale: Choice B is the best answer because 'a straightforward explanation' implies that a simple, clear explanation is lacking, which is why complex modeling is needed to understand planet formation in binary star systems.

questions.passage: Award-winning travel writer Linda Watanabe McFerrin considers the background research she conducts on destinations featured in her travel books to be its own reward. ______blank McFerrin admits to finding the research phase of her work just as fascinating and engaging as exploring a location in person.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?
questions.rationale: Choice B is the best answer because 'In fact,' emphasizes and reinforces McFerrin's claim that the research phase is as rewarding as direct exploration.

questions.passage: The recent discovery of a carved wooden figure dating to around 2,000 years ago in a ditch in England was truly surprising. Wooden objects ______blank survive for so long due to their high susceptibility to rot, but archaeologists suspect layers of sediment in the ditch preserved the figure by creating an oxygen-free environment.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?
questions.rationale: Choice C is the best answer because 'rarely' conveys that it is uncommon for wooden objects to survive for such long periods due to their tendency to rot, making the discovery notable.

questions.passage: According to statistician Nassim Nicholas Taleb, the best way to predict the amount of time a nonperishable entity (such as a building or a technology) will continue to exist is to examine how long it has survived so far. In this view, an item’s age is the strongest ______blank how much longer it will last.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?
questions.rationale: Choice B is the best answer because 'indicator' means something that shows or suggests a condition. Here, an item’s age serves as an indicator of its potential longevity.

questions.passage: In 1873, Spanish scientist Santiago Ramón y Cajal observed that brain fibers have distinct boundaries with clear end points, a finding that went against earlier assumptions about the brain. ______blank scientists had assumed that the brain was a continuous web of fused fibers, not a vast network of distinct, individual cells.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?
questions.rationale: Choice B is the best answer because 'Previously,' indicates that the earlier belief (that the brain was a continuous web) existed before Ramón y Cajal’s discovery, setting up the contrast between past assumptions and his findings.

questions.passage: Okot p’Bitek’s poem Song of Lawino (1966) explores postcolonial Ugandan life through the eyes of a woman living in a rural village. With its vibrant imagery, bitingly satiric tone, and dexterous use of traditional Acholi song and phraseology, the poem inspired a generation of East African writers. ______blank those who adopted its style are often referred to as Okot School poets.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?
questions.rationale: Choice B is the best answer. 'Fittingly' means appropriately or suitably, and it indicates that writers who adopted Okot p’Bitek’s style were appropriately called the Okot School poets.

questions.passage: Before the 1847 introduction of the US postage stamp, the cost of postage was usually paid by the recipient of a letter rather than the sender, and recipients were not always able or willing to pay promptly. ______blank collecting this fee could be slow and arduous, and heaps of unpaid-for, undeliverable mail piled up in post offices.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?
questions.rationale: Choice C is the best answer. 'Consequently' signals that the difficulties in collecting the fee led to slow, arduous processes and piles of undeliverable mail.

questions.passage: A potter choosing which type of clay to use for a piece considers two key factors: the desired look of the piece and its intended use. ______blank earthenware clay is often used for decorative pieces because of its rustic look. This type of clay is not often used in industrial settings, though, because it is less durable than other clays.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?
questions.rationale: Choice D is the best answer. 'For example,' indicates that the sentence that follows provides an illustration—earthenware clay being used for decorative purposes.

questions.passage: In Gothic architecture, flying buttresses are large arches that help support a building’s exterior walls. Before the Gothic era, cathedrals’ heavy ceilings had to be supported by thick, short walls, but the invention of flying buttresses eliminated this need. ______blank Gothic cathedrals could be built with thinner, higher walls.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?
questions.rationale: Choice D is the best answer. 'As a result,' indicates that because of flying buttresses, the structural support requirements changed, allowing for thinner, higher walls.

questions.passage: Tyrian purple was a highly prized dye among the Phoenicians (an ancient civilization located in present-day Lebanon). The Phoenicians were famous for using this natural dye to color their clothes a distinctive purple. ______blank the name 'Phoenicia' itself, some historians claim, may have originally meant 'land of purple.'
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?
questions.rationale: Choice A is the best answer. 'In fact,' signals that the detail about the possible meaning of 'Phoenicia' reinforces the earlier claim about the prominence of purple dye in Phoenician culture.

questions.passage: Etched into Peru’s Nazca Desert are line drawings so large that they can only be fully seen from high above. Archaeologists have known of the lines since the 1920s, when a researcher spotted some from a nearby foothill, and they have been studying the markings ever since. ______blank archaeologists’ efforts are aided by drones that capture high-resolution aerial photographs of the lines.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?
questions.rationale: Choice A is the best answer. 'Currently,' emphasizes that the use of drone technology is a present-day method aiding ongoing archaeological research in the Nazca Desert.

questions.passage: Because an achiral molecule is symmetrical, flipping it yields a structurally identical molecule. A flipped chiral molecule, ______blank can be compared to a glove that has been turned inside out: it produces a structurally inverted molecule rather than an identical one.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?
questions.rationale: Choice B is the best answer. 'By contrast,' signals a difference: while achiral molecules yield identical structures when flipped, chiral molecules do not, much like turning a glove inside out.

questions.passage: Most conifers (trees belonging to the phylum Coniferophyta) are evergreen. That is, they keep their green leaves or needles year-round. However, not all conifer species are evergreen. Larch trees, ______blank lose their needles every fall.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?
questions.rationale: Choice A is the best answer. 'For instance,' introduces larch trees as an example of a conifer species that does not retain its needles year-round.

questions.passage: Jhumpa Lahiri’s story collection Interpreter of Maladies features multiple stories about romantic relationships. In 'This Blessed House,' newlyweds argue over whether to replace items left by the previous owners of their new home. ______blank in 'A Temporary Matter,' a husband and wife attempt to rekindle their relationship during a four-night blackout.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?
questions.rationale: Choice C is the best answer. 'Likewise,' signals that the scenario in 'A Temporary Matter' is similar in context to the argument in 'This Blessed House,' both exploring aspects of interpersonal relationships.

questions.passage: Small, flat structures called spatulae are found at the tips of the hairs on a spider’s leg. These spatulae temporarily bond with the atoms of whatever they touch. ______blank spiders are able to cling to and climb almost any surface.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?
questions.rationale: Choice D is the best answer. 'As a result,' indicates that the bonding properties of the spatulae enable spiders to effectively cling to various surfaces.

questions.passage: As a young historian in the 1950s, Alixa Naff began interviewing fellow Arab American immigrants about their experiences straddling two cultures. Over the next few decades, Naff conducted more than 450 such interviews, also known as oral histories. ______blank she collected photographs and other artifacts that represented her subjects’ experiences.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?
questions.rationale: Choice C is the best answer. 'In addition,' signals that besides conducting interviews, Naff also gathered additional artifacts to complement her research.

questions.passage: Before California’s 1911 election to approve a proposition granting women the right to vote, activists across the state sold tea to promote the cause of suffrage. In San Francisco, the Woman’s Suffrage Party sold Equality Tea at local fairs. ______blank in Los Angeles, activist Nancy Tuttle Craig, who ran one of California’s largest grocery store firms, distributed Votes for Women Tea.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?
questions.rationale: Choice C is the best answer. 'Similarly,' indicates that the tea-selling activity in Los Angeles paralleled the one in San Francisco, thereby supporting the idea that activists nationwide used tea to promote suffrage.

questions.passage: In 2019, researcher Patricia Jurado Gonzalez and food historian Nawal Nasrallah prepared a stew from a 4,000-year-old recipe found on a Mesopotamian clay tablet. When they tasted the dish, known as pašrūtum (“unwinding”), they found that it had a mild taste and inspired a sense of calm. ______blank the researchers, knowing that dishes were sometimes named after their intended effects, theorized that the dish’s name, 'unwinding,' referred to its function: to help ancient diners relax.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?
questions.rationale: Choice A is the best answer. 'Therefore,' signals that the researchers’ theory about the dish's name is a logical conclusion drawn from the observation that the dish had a calming effect.

questions.passage: Neuroscientist Karen Konkoly wanted to determine whether individuals can understand and respond to questions during REM sleep. She first taught volunteers eye movements they would use to respond to basic math problems while asleep (a single left-right eye movement indicated the number one). ______blank she attached electrodes to the volunteers’ faces to record their eye movements during sleep.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?
questions.rationale: Choice B is the best answer. 'Next,' clearly indicates that the action of attaching electrodes follows as the subsequent step in Konkoly's experiment.

questions.passage: In June, female loggerhead sea turtles will swim back to the sandy beaches where they were born to lay eggs of their own. First, the turtle will dig her nest in the sand. ______blank she will lay up to 100 eggs in the nest. Finally, she will cover it all with sand, before returning to the ocean.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?
questions.rationale: Choice C is the best answer. 'Next,' indicates that the egg-laying step follows nest digging in the sequence of events described.
